title: Damage Control During Domain Adaptation for Transducer Based Automatic Speech Recognition

last_post.content: An interesting paper by #NVIDA describing methods to adapt end-to-end #speechrecognition models to a new domain without using any data from the original domain and minimizing catastrophic forgetting 😎. Speech commands are still very tricky though because of short length (no context): https://arxiv.org/abs/2210.03255

If you're doing humanistic research into AI, this is possibly the most meaningful article to consider of the past year, both for the findings of the authors' "algorithmic audit" of an HRT transgender dataset but also for the methodology itself. https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/20539517221113772

BioGPT has been released by Microsoft Research. Model of language developed using PubMed-sourced biomedical research literature. On PubMedQA, the model performs better than humans when answering questions from the biomedical literature. The model's source code has been made available to the public, and the weights for the substantial 1.5B model are anticipated to follow shortly after

GitHub repository: https://github.com/microsoft/BioGPT

Article: https://academic.oup.com/bib/article/23/6/bbac409/6713511

Congratulations to all involved in achieving this milestone.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning and the Deadly Triad

last_post.content:
(3) RL agents trained offline are known to overestimate the Q-value on unseen actions, and thus underperform during deployment ( https://arxiv.org/abs/1812.02648).
This is due to the optimizer's curse, i.e., the agent selects the action with highest Q-value, which is likely overestimated.

Following a trail from John Naughton’s article about the fediverse restoring human communication, I read his previous article on ChatGPT, and that took me to Murray Shanahan on human language, and LLM models as predictive sequences of words designed to seem likely.

“Sequences of words with a propositional form are not special to the model itself in the way they are to us. The model itself has no notion of truth or falsehood, properly speaking, because it lacks the means to exercise these concepts in anything like the way we do.”

This is helping me to understand my feeling that what is at stake here is compositional language that is special to us. It matters, for this profound reason.

title: Extracting Training Data from Diffusion Models

last_post.content:
This time Google does the right thing - while shareholders grill them over "competition" with ChatGPT (not really...), they research and publish how useful and privacy preserving large models are.

It turns out, as suspected, they are not very useful for actual professional writers who understand "something" about writing: https://arxiv.org/abs/2211.05030

...and leak the dataset/private data, 2x worse with diffusion than GANs: https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.13188

No wonder Google is hesitant to use them. :)

https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07733
'Learning-Rate-Free Learning by D-Adaptation'
- Aaron Defazio, Konstantin Mishchenko

The informational complexity of optimising convex, Lipschitz functions depends on the distance of the initial state to the true minimiser, which is typically unknown in practice. This work presents an adaptive scheme for estimating this distance, and shows that the resulting algorithm is then essentially rate-optimal, up to log factors.

title: Understanding and Detecting Hallucinations in Neural Machine Translation via Model Introspection

last_post.content: Detecting hallucinations in machine translation using model internals is a hot topic! 🔥 Very nice work by @weijiavxu@twitter.com, @swetaagrawal20@twitter.com et al. out on @arxiv@twitter.com today showing promising result in that direction: https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07779

The really confronting thing about this new article on feedback loops in #climatechange is the staggering number of loops and mechanisms in play:

41 feedback loops (20 physical and 21 biological) are mentioned, showing the huge risk exposure that planet Earth is facing as a consequence of our continuing reliance upon and addiction to #fossilfuels

The abstract image displays some of these major feedback loops, but if you want a better understanding of both the risks posed and the interplay between them, check out this new article in One Earth on:

https://doi.org/10.1016/j.oneear.2023.01.004

#ClimateCrisis

https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.11479
/Alien Coding/
Thibault Gauthier, Miroslav Olšák, Josef Urban

Abstract (abridged)
We introduce a self-learning algorithm for synthesizing programs for OEIS sequences. (...) Then it runs many iterations of a self-learning loop that interleaves (i) training neural machine translation to learn the correspondence between sequences and the programs discovered so far, and (ii) proposing many new programs for each OEIS sequence by the trained neural machine translator.

Nice to see pushback to the idea of positionality statements that has been spreading in psychology. https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/17456916221144988 All contructivist researchers of course disagree. But as constructivist approaches are in direct opposition to my philosophy of science, that is fine. I agree with the authors that positionality statements should not be part of science. If you want to use them, do so only after reflecting on whether they actually align with your philosophy of science.

title: BLIP: Bootstrapping Language-Image Pre-training for Unified Vision-Language Understanding and Generation

last_post.content:
Went back to BLIP (https://arxiv.org/abs/2201.12086) last night. When I first skimmed it, I focused on the part of the paper focused on bootstrapping captions, but the "Multimodal mixture of Encoder-Decoder" architecture is pretty cool.

It uses a structured architecture involving multiple encoder/decoders wherein some parts of the architecture take advantage of others (e.g. using the contrastive loss for hard example mining for the image-text matching loss).

#ilp #vlp #multimodal

From the January 4th issue of our newsletter...

*Language models as agent models*

Jacob Andreas argues that big language models can, at least in some very narrow situations, “model agency and communicative intent”, without being “in any general sense human-like”. His research and explanation make for a good case. The paper is clear, accessible, and an important read for anyone following language model debates. (28 min).

title: Position prediction using disturbance observer for planar pushing

title: Linear Convergence of Gradient and Proximal-Gradient Methods Under the Polyak-Łojasiewicz Condition

last_post.content:
Polyak-Łojasiewicz inequality generalizes strong convexity, and a simple condition to ensure linear converge of gradient descent even for non-convex functions. You should read the very nice and clear paper of @MarkSchmidtUBC and collaborators about this!
https://arxiv.org/abs/1608.04636

title: Precise Zero-Shot Dense Retrieval without Relevance Labels

last_post.content:
Interesting method where instead of directly trying to connect a query to an embedding space , they came up with likely wrong answers and found those in embedding space first, which worked better.
